ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about primate and hominin evolution, and the behaviors and neurological functions that make humans unique. I also learned how to effectively read scientific literature, and improved my research paper writing skills.
I learned details about the history of human evolution, as well as explored experiments and tests to see what makes the human mind so unique.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that this class was strong in generating interesting discussions, but it could have been improved with more structured class time. For instance, half of class could be dedicated to discussion, and then the other half of the class could be dedicated to the presentation or videos to make sure we got to everything. I also think that some of our writing assignments could have been a bit more specific, because it was difficult to choose topics when the prompt was that we could write about anything.

The only weakness of the class is the location it was taught in. The content of this class was very interesting and I especially enjoyed the study of skull casts as well as the viewing of videos Professor watts took himself of chimps.

The content of this course was very interesting and well-taught, but class discussions lacked direction and energy. I think engagement with the material could be improved through more interactive class discussions and the implementation of smaller group discussions surrounding the readings and any questions/ideas that we may have had. Thus, improving the class environment will help students engage with the course materials at a higher level.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course, but only to students who are genuinely interested in anthropology and primates. The workload isn't bad - there are weekly readings (you do have to do at least some of them to get something out of class discussion) and a few papers. Prof. Watts is great and can answer pretty much any question you have. However, if you aren't all that interested in the course material, it can get boring.

I would recommend this to anyone who is interested in anthropology and/or primates and doesn't have a lot of experience in the subject. I came in with very little knowledge of anthropology, but it wasn't too difficult for me to understand anything that was presented, and I learned a decent amount.
Yes. Mr Watts is super enthusiastic about this subject. So knowledgeable it is inspiring
Yes! I think this course allows you to learn about human evolution to an extent that high school courses did not allow. Its a super neat subject to explore, even if anthro isnt your major.
